awd_titl_txt: Somatosensory Feature Encoding and Attentional Modulation in Human Neocortex
awd_abstract_narration:
As people search through their pockets to find items, they are able to seamlessly toggle attention from their left hand to their right hand and back to their left hand. Spatial attention enables the brain to effortlessly and selectively perceive and understand what is in the left or right hand at any given moment. Despite the obvious importance of attentional processing for bimanual perception and the coordination of hand movements, how spatial attention deployment to the hands modulates the encoding of touch information remains poorly understood. This research investigates the effects of spatial attention on touch. This project is expected to impact society by advancing understanding of the brain mechanisms supporting touch and attentional selection on the hands, which could enhance diagnosis and monitoring of sensorimotor dysfunctions, and inform the design of advanced neuroprosthetics. The project will promote the participation and education of community college students in neuroscience and related STEM fields.  

Using computational neuroimaging methods and non-invasive brain stimulation, this research will elucidate the effects of spatial attention on information encoding and signal transmission in the human somatosensory cortex. A major research objective is to characterize spatial attention effects on somatosensory stimulus encoding. This objective will be achieved using novel fMRI encoding models that describe population-level tuning for vibration frequency information. These models will be used to establish where and how spatial attention signals – and their potential interaction with limb position manipulations – modulate the encoded vibration representations in the human brain. A second major research objective is to characterize spatial attention effects on signal transmission in the somatosensory cortical system. This objective will be achieved by combining causal manipulations of brain activity, using transcranial magnetic stimulation, with behavioral experiments and functional neuroimaging. These multimodal approaches will be used to establish state-dependent processing principles in the somatosensory system. Collectively, the research program will yield novel insights into how spatial attention to the hands flexibly shapes somatosensory feature encoding and network communication in human neocortex.

por.por_cntn:
Our research team investigated the nature of spatial attention processing in our sense of touch. The deployment of tactile spatial attention is an intuitive process that we use regularly without thinking as in when you reach into your pants pockets to retrieve your keys stored in one pocket.

We set out to ask two main questions. First, we investigated how the act of directing your attention to either your left hand or your right hand changes how your brain represents information about what is touching your hand. We asked research volunteers to feel and judge vibrations on their hands while they underwent functional neuroimaging. We measured brain activity changes related to the vibrations and determined the effects of attention deployment as well as the effects of positioning the hands close together or far apart. We found that the brain activity associated with the same set of vibrations differed depending on whether you attended to the hand and how far the hands were separated. These results reveal that the parts of the nervous system supporting perception on your hands are strongly affected by how your attend to your hands and where you place your hands in space. 

Our second question was aimed at determining how tactile spatial attention changes communication between brain regions supporting touch. A classical view of the brain is that one hemisphere supports processing for the hand on the opposite side of your body (and the other hemisphere supports processing for the 2nd hand). We investigated how the communication between the two hemispheres depended on how you deploy your attention to your hands. We used non-invasive brain stimulation (with magnets) as a tool for probing the communication between the two hemispheres. In behavior experiments, we tested how brain stimulation targeting one hemisphere disrupts volunteers' ability to detect light touch on one or both hands depending on attention. In functional neuroimaging experiments, we tested how brain stimulation targeting one hemisphere is associated with distributed brain activity changes in the two brain hemispheres depending on attention. These experiments establish that the deployment of spatial attention over the two hands changes in the communication between the two hemispheres.  

Our work provides insight into how spatial attention impacts information processing in the human brain. This work may inform our understanding of how the brain functions in individuals with disrupted attention processing. Additionally, this work may inform the design of brain computer interfaces aimed at restoring touch in those who have lost sensation.
